title: Conflict Styles
description: Discover how you naturally approach disagreements and differences.

questions.text: When a disagreement arises, my natural instinct is to...
choices: Address it directly and work it out
Take time to think before responding
Avoid it if possible—conflict is uncomfortable
Depend on how important the issue is

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict approach reveals attachment and coping patterns. Direct-addressers engage immediately; thinkers need processing time; avoiders find conflict threatening; importance-weighers are strategic. Mismatched styles cause frustration.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The direct-addresser may feel the avoider doesn't care; the avoider may feel the direct-addresser is aggressive. Neither is wrong—find your shared pace.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conflict approach makes navigating disagreements smoother. You'll naturally move at the same speed.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you typically respond when conflict arises? Where did you learn that pattern?

questions.text: During an argument, I tend to...
choices: Stay focused on the issue at hand
Get emotional and need to express feelings
Shut down and need space
Try to find a quick resolution

therapeutic.rationale: Argument behavior reveals regulation patterns. Issue-focusers stay logical; emotion-expressers need to release; shut-downers get overwhelmed; quick-resolvers want peace. Understanding your partner's pattern prevents escalation.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The emotion-expresser may feel the shut-downer doesn't care; the shut-downer may feel flooded by emotion. Both need different things to feel safe.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched argument patterns help you navigate conflict similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens to you during an argument? What do you need in those moments?

questions.text: The thing I find hardest about conflict is...
choices: Staying calm when I'm upset
Feeling like we're disconnected
Worrying it means something's wrong with us
Not knowing when or how it will resolve

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict challenges reveal vulnerabilities. Calm-strugglers have regulation difficulty; disconnection-feelers have attachment anxiety; worry-types catastrophize; uncertainty-strugglers need resolution. Naming your challenge helps your partner support you.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different challenges need different support. The disconnection-feeler needs reassurance; the uncertainty-struggler needs a path forward.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared challenges create mutual understanding of what's hard about conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's hardest for you about conflict? What would make it easier?

questions.text: I believe conflict in a relationship is...
choices: Normal and can be healthy if handled well
Something to minimize as much as possible
An opportunity to understand each other better
Uncomfortable but necessary sometimes

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict beliefs shape how you engage. Normal-viewers accept it; minimizers avoid; opportunity-seers embrace it; necessary-evil types tolerate it. Beliefs affect whether conflict is productive or destructive.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The opportunity-seer may seem to invite conflict; the minimizer may seem to suppress important issues. Both have wisdom—find balance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conflict beliefs create aligned expectations about disagreements.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you believe about conflict in relationships? Where did that belief come from?

questions.text: After a conflict, what I most need is...
choices: Reassurance that we're okay
Time and space to recover
To talk through what happened
Physical reconnection

therapeutic.rationale: Post-conflict needs vary. Reassurance-seekers need relationship security; space-needers need recovery time; talkers need processing; physical-reconnectors need touch. Giving the wrong thing delays healing.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The reassurance-seeker may feel abandoned by the space-needer's withdrawal; the space-needer may feel smothered by pursuit. Name your needs before conflict.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched recovery needs make post-conflict reconnection smoother.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need after a conflict? Does your partner know?
